top_comment.text:
Krzysiu, mam pytanie. Słyszałam kiedyś, że tak jak my widzimy ludzi z 
Japonii i innych podobnych narodów jako praktycznie niemal takich samych, 
to tak samo oni widzą nas. Czy to prawda?﻿
top_comment.author: Phenylethylamine

comments.text: ps. no chyba, ze jesteś rudy. Wtedy Ciebie nie pomylą ;)
comments.author: luu .hee

comments.text:
+Phenylethylamine
 Bywam w Singapurze i dla Azjatów też jesteśmy tacy sami, nawet kolor 
włosów nie ma znaczenia. KONIEC I KROPKA :)
no chyba, ze znają ciebie bliżej to potrafią odróżnić .. my też odróżniamy 
bliżej znanych nam Azjatów od innych :)
comments.author: luu .hee

comments.text:
+Paula Lizak chodziło mi bardziej o to, że patrząc na azjatów, trudno 
rozróżnić często jednego od drugiego tak bardzo są wszyscy podobni do 
siebie. U nas tego problemu nie ma, wszyscy mają inne kolory włosów, 
zupełnie inne twarze, oczy. U nich wszyscy mają takie same cechy urody. I 
podobno my dla nich też jesteśmy tacy sami.
comments.author: Phenylethylamine

comments.text: prawda
comments.author: luu .hee

comments.text:
Jak widzisz obcego człowieka na ulicy to wiesz, czy jest z Niemiec, Francji 
czy Kanady? Ja raczej nie, w Azji jest podobnie, niektóre narodowości mają 
jakieś specyficzne cechy, ale z drugiej strony np. Norwegowie też 
najczęściej są bladzi i mają jasne rude albo blond włosy. My to wiemy, ale 
azjaci niekoniecznie. To działa w obie strony, nawet w trzy, same story z 
murzynami, przepraszam, Afroamerykanami
comments.author: Paula Lizak

comments.text: Tak, to prawda.

dziwnie?﻿

publicznych. Stąd moje domysły i pytanie.

comments.text:
Japończycy sami atakują kamerami każdy zwiedzany zakątek świata, pojawienie 
się w barze z kamerą, czy gdzie indziej jest zupełnie zlewane, nawet ludzie 
zlewają fakt, że i twarz może się dostać do jakiegoś materiału.

Może Krzysztof musiał wypić jak podliczył koszta kręcenia filmików w

Chociaż patrząc na swoje filmy, to troszkę zazdroszczę jemu takiej

comments.author: Janek Gada

comments.text: cały świat pije :)
comments.author: Jedrzej Sadecki

top_comment.text:
Krzysztof jest hardcorem z powodu tego ślimaka :D.
U nas z piwem jest lepiej? Prawie żadne piwo nie zawiera czystego chmielu, 
a proszek i chemię, czytaj - ekstrakt.
Większość piw jest tak niedobra, iż nie da się tego pić. Za dobre piwo w 
sklepach płaci się od 4 do 5 złotych. Wyjątkiem w cenie i smaku jest Tyskie 
Klasyczne (złota etykieta), gdzie jest bardzo tanie, ma chmiel i jest 
pyszne. Wyjątkami są jeszcze Żywiec (z chmielem) i Tyskie Gronie, które to 
chmielu nie posiada jednak jest dobre. Oczywiście znalazłoby się jeszcze 
kilka wyjątków.
"Piwa" typu Tatra, Harnaś, Wojak winny być po 10 groszy, a patykiem bym 
tego nie dotknął.﻿
top_comment.author: mraksss

comments.text:
Polecam pooglądać trochę vloga Tomasza Kopyry to ci się trochę poszerzą 
choryzonty. Każde piwo które znajdziecie w standardowym markecie to jedno i 
to samo: międzynarodowy lager czyli dużo gazu, bardzo mało chmielu. 
Poszukajcie specjalistycznego sklepu w okolicy. Poproście np o "Atak 
chmielu" to zobaczycie co to goryczka. A to piwo ma 58 ibu(czyli jednostek 
goryczy) a zdażają się i takie co mają 100. Piwa koncernowe mają max 13.
comments.author: danielwacek

comments.text:
Wasza dyskusja jest jałowa z definicji, jeśli ktokolwiek podaje, że tyskie 
jest dobre, jak i fakt, że kłotnia dotyczy koncerniaków. LUDZIE. Pracownia 
Piwa, Browar Wąsosz, Pinta, Ale Browar - to tak na instancie.
Chcecie chmiel to kupcie sobie atak chmielu albo rowing jacka, a jak ktoś 
będzie mial czelność mówić, że za piwo w butelce nie zapłaci 7-8zł (bar 
10-12, a kupuje tyskie za 6-8zł w knajpie) to pozdrawiam
comments.author: zygfrodo

comments.text:
Miłosław, Lwówek, Rycerskie... Oj, jeśli chodzi o piwo to Polska jest 
pięknym krajem :D
comments.author: BzykN7

comments.text:
Taa... Tyskie i Harnaś to dwa różne światy...
Jedno to średnie piwo z średniej półki cenowej, a drugie to... średnie piwo 
z niskiej półki cenowej.
Częściej zdarza mi się pić to pierwsze, ale żadnego z wyżej wymienionych 
nie nazwałbym naprawdę dobrym piwem. Tyskie Klasyczne było przez pierwszy 
miesiąc pyszne i zawierało dużą ilość ekstraktów. Kiedy poszło w Polskę 
jakość spadła odpowiednio do ceny i w tej chwili nie wyróżnia się niczym.
Tak jak napisałeś za dobre piwo płaci się (zazwyczaj) 4 do 5 złotych, a 
nierzadko więcej.
comments.author: xSebun

comments.text:
Coś dużo tych wyjątków się znalazło w tej krótkiej liście. Mocno 
przesadzone narzekanie. Wybór piw jest duży, jeśli komuś wystarczają ścieki 
z wielkoskalowej produkcji to kupuje bro za 2 zł. Ja bez problemu znajduję 
piwa naturalnie ważone i sobie chwalę.
comments.author: S3ba11

comments.text: Tyskie Klasyczne najlepsze ;)
comments.author: SzefoSZF

comments.text:
Wydaje mi się że " u nas jest lepiej" odnosiło się do dostępności piw 
lokalnych i z tzw "minibrowarów"
comments.author: Bartłomiej “Jsatrzab” Jastrzębski

comments.text:
Wg mnie nie jest zle, przede wszystkim wybor jest ogromny, wiec zawsze ktos 
znajdzie cos dla siebie.
comments.author: Chmielok

comments.author: Michał Zahora

captions.text: We're in this type of joint known in Japan as Izakaya
it's basically like a... boozer I guess.
But izakayas are usually serving food to go with the booze as well.
No, I mean - they always serve food as well.
Bar snacks, nibbles and stuff.
Right, let's start with those teapots
they are booze-pots actually, with nihonshu, commonly known as 'sake'.
A handy tip for those of you travelling to Japan:
'sake' literally means 'alcohol', so if you order 'sake'
they'll have no idea what you're talking about.
The more you know.
I've got this amazing bar snack here, really great stuff
it's a basically a crab shell,
filled with minced crab, sort of crab paste.
That you have to grill.
What do we have here - first one is nigori,
smells very fruity, looks cloudy
it's a type of wine. Good, let's try it.
Very sweet, very soft in taste
as our friend here says, it's quite popular with girls.
Doesn't look pretty, but oh well.
We'll just have to like, grab it with the chopsticks.
Those two pots are filled with stronger stuff
even the smell is more intense.
And yes, it tastes stronger indeed. Still, very nice stuff.
This seems to be a common thing with all kinds of sake in Japan, actually.
I didn't use to like sake back in Poland.
Let's try the third one.
So yeah, sake in Poland had this, cheap wine kind of flavour
I only started really digging it after I moved here.
The third one was beautiful, just as the second one.
Nori flakes, they're good.
Dried shrimp, and a thing called 'eihire'
which is a.. dried fin? Dried ray fin? Something like this?
Also decent.
We've just ordered some more alien looking seafood here
a nice big shrimp over here,
grilling nice and steady,
I'm down for this one.
But there's this other thing as well, tsuboyaki
which literally means
cooked... fried shell, basically there's a living creature inside of it
I mean it's been long dead, but still.
This is very me. When it comes to extreme cuisine.
You have to force it out with the pincers
like, really work those pincers.
Right...
This does look so very appetizing.
I've got to say, even for me this is... pretty hardcore.
Dear God, I'm not even going to pretend
Let's just say we wanted to do this thing again,
where I try something weird and find it completely disgusting.
I'm not even going to try this time, seriously.
This is just revolting.
I'll cut it all up - the problem with this type of seafood is
that if they're too big, it just doesn't... ugh.
Interesting. A little bit bitter.
This is the worst part, because it's quite hard to chew, a bit crunchy even.
No, it's cool actually. The first time I tried it I almost barfed
I just wasn't ready for the texture.
This last part is full of gristle
makes this crunchy sound when you chew it, like chicken gristle.
Not that bad, when you know that's what's coming.
Dude, how can you leave the shrimp head out.

- I'm not...
- This is the best part of the shrimp!
- I'm not a barbarian, to be eating someone's head.
- You're useless and know nothing.
Next two types of Japanese alcohol are
well, this one is 'umeshu'
it's a plum wine, made of sweet ume plums.
And yes, it's very sweet. You can get it in Poland as well, actually.
Of course, what you get in Poland is just like sake in Poland
usually brewed in Germany.
So. I'd be careful with forming my opinion on umeshu based on what's available back home
I think they even call it incorrectly, as 'ume'.
Abusing the language again.
As I already said, it's very sweet - not really my kind of thing.
This stuff though, shochu, which is very similar to Korean soju
I don't think it's a coincidence.
First of all, it's got rather unusual strenght,
it's about 25%,
a volume that's quite rare, at least in our culture.
Not a very common one.
Taste is... well, it's a difficult type of alcohol
most people wouldn't like it, I think.
It's like a stronger version of sake.
This thing here is called 'sour',
shochu mixed with soda, there are million kinds of it.
This particular one is called 'yuzu + honey'
yuzu being a Japanese citrus, similar to lime
and honey, well, that's just honey, I mean.
Duh.
I like it, very easy to drink.
That's considered 'girly', right?
Dangerous thing, the type of thing you can just down like it's a soft drink.
And then you wake up feeling like a train wreck.
Moving on to the next one - this is so called 'highball'
which is whiskey with soda.
The funny thing is - as much as it's nothing special really, not something exclusively Japanese
they're insanely popular here.
Almost beer level popular.
If you go to a bar, you always have a huge selection of highballs, same price as beer.
They've got their own separate section in a drinks menu.
Very, very popular.
Of course beer is also a common drink in Japan
the beer industry here is almost completely dominated by huge beverage companies,
that produce both booze and soft drinks.
Asahi, Kirin, Suntory or Sapporo.
To be honest, they're not remarkable beers
but to try and find something more local
more interesting, a craft beer, a microbrew
you really have to dig deep.
We didn't even try to go there.
That's the one single thing we've got figured out back home.
Highball is definitely my drink of choice here
if I want to order something and get, how to put it...
casually tipsy, this would be the equivallent to my usual pint.
Apart from the bars and other drinking establishments
Japanese drinking culture is also cultivated at home..
- Yeah, house parties, other parties...
- Or by the river, when it gets warm.
On the beach.
Yeah, you can legally drink on the street here.
They don't do it often though,
it's not a common view, is it? Somebody just walking around with a can of beer.
- Well yes, eating and drinking on the go is a bit of a tricky subject here.
- It's not a classy thing to do, put it that way.
- So, try not to.
- Before we forget, we bought a little something to show you.
- This is the cheapest, lousy supermarket sake.
- And I mean: cheapest.
- This one is ridiculous, comes in a juice box. A 100 yen worth of cheap sake.
- Even less sometimes, right?

- So that's less than a dollar.
- Yup.
- And the taste is - not gonna lie, you can taste it's cheap booze,
- but I wouldn't say it's any worse than the sake you can buy in Poland
- Or what goes by the name of 'sake' in Poland. And is crazy expensive.
- Remember it next time you spend silly money on sake.

- And this is sake as well.
- That's right.
- Sake in a mason jar.
- Looks like some sort of moonshine? In a jar?
- That's what it technically is though, moonshine in a jar, only rice based.
- This thing isn't sake, but it's nevertheless legendary: Strong, our personal favourite
- Yeah, definitely our drink of choice.
- Meaning 'the one we choose to buy most often'

- It's decent, citrusy-flavoured...
- A good alternative to your usual after hours beer.
- Your head doesn't feel heavy, and you're not gonna get drunk on just one
- Tasty, 9% strong. And it's cheap.
- How much is it, like 200 yen?
- And a can of decent beer is 300.
- You can't get a proper one for 200.

- So it's cheaper, better...
- And there are different flavours.
- Yeah, there's lemon, lime... Mostly that type of fruit, isn't it?
- Or the sweet candy-like flavours.
- So this is it, our official recommendation.
- That was our brief take of the Japanese drinking culture
and it's different types.
Thanks for watching,
now you're that much wiser as to what's popular here. In terms of booze.
- Cool, we're done. Let's go grab a drink.

title: Alkohole w Japonii - sake, schochu, umeshu, Izakaya [Tokio] // Japanese drinking culture [Eng subs]
